awd_titl_txt: CyberWatch West: Securing the Cyber West
awd_abstract_narration:
Keeping computers and information systems secure is a major challenge. Business, industry, and government need well-prepared technicians who can prevent, detect, and investigate cybersecurity breaches, and the growth of cyber-threats has created a need for many more workers who have appropriate, specific knowledge and skills. To address these needs, CyberWatch West (CWW; http://cyberwatchwest.org), an Advanced Technological Education (ATE) regional center, will continue its activities that are strengthening and expanding cybersecurity education in the Western region of the United States. This area is home to many high-tech companies, utilities, government agencies, and nonprofit organizations, which need a healthy supply of employees with cybersecurity knowledge and skills at all levels. CWW's cybersecurity education programs, hands-on cyber competitions and training workshops, approaches to faculty and student development, and industry engagement initiatives are proven models that should be shared broadly across the West and the nation. In cooperation with industry and government partners, CWW will educate students to fill thousands of job openings in cybersecurity and will thereby address national needs for the security of critical infrastructure, defense, healthcare, and commerce.

CWW was previously funded through NSF Awards DUE-1104278 and DUE-1361636. The center's mission is to strengthen the cybersecurity workforce in the Western United States by providing solutions to address the limited resources at community colleges through innovative curriculum development; building an online community for faculty professional growth and mentoring; creating a developmental pathway of competitions that facilitate growth of students' cybersecurity skills; and supporting other efforts at the state, regional, and national levels to develop and disseminate cybersecurity programs. The center will disseminate its model cybersecurity education programs throughout a 14-state region; expand curriculum development, faculty professional development, and student development opportunities; and strengthen and sustain industry partnerships to ensure up-to-date curricula as well as student internships and employment. In particular, CWW will support institutions seeking the National Center of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance 2-Year Education (CAE2Y) designation. The center will develop model curricula that meet CAE2Y Knowledge Unit (KU) criteria and National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education (NICE) criteria addressing workforce readiness. Expanding CWW's past work on "2 + 2 + 2" educational pathways, the center will develop a cybersecurity Transfer Model Curriculum (TMC) to facilitate automatic transfer for California community college students to universities in the California State University system. CWW will further serve college faculty in the region by addressing new topics and content in cybersecurity via webinars, workshops, the CWW website, and an innovative faculty mentoring program.

por.por_cntn:
Partnering organizations:

  • California State University, San Bernardino (Tony Coulson, Co-PI)
  • Eastern New Mexico University - Ruidoso Branch Community College (Stephen Miller, Co-PI)
  • California State Polytechnic University, Pomona (Dan Manson, Co-PI, retired)
  • Coastline Community College (Nancy Jones, former Co-PI)

The CyberWatch West (CWW): Securing the West award in 2015 expanded upon a previous regional center grant at Whatcom Community College (WCC), with the goal to strengthen and expand upon the number of qualified cybersecurity professionals in the western region of the United States. The proposal focused on:

  • Expanding and promoting CWW's model cybersecurity education programs throughout a 13 state region to member schools, colleges and universities;
  • Continuing and growing curriculum development, faculty professional development and student development opportunities;
  • Strengthening and sustaining industry partnerships for high-value connections and relationships to ensure currency of curriculum, student internship and employment, and for participation in member colleges' efforts.

Results:
CWW's expanded reach is well documented. Its growing national status and impact was recognized with additional large NSF grant awards in 2018-19, and the name was changed to NCyTE--The National Cybersecurity Training & Education Center to reflect the expansion. In fall, 2021 NCyTE became the NSF ATE national center for cybersecurity education through a $7.5M award to WCC for at least five years.


GOAL 1: Strengthen cybersecurity education in the Western region of the US and collaborate with other ATE centers to meet the demand for cybersecurity education, career pathways, and workforce development.

 
During the grant period, CWW/NCyTE continued to expand into new states, growing from members in only six states in 2013 to 44 states and Puerto Rico by 2021. Institutional membership grew from 33 in 2013 to 314 as of August 2021. Membership consists of high schools, community colleges and universities (roughly 1/3 each).
NCyTE worked closely with National CyberWatch and with CSSIA--Center for Systems Security & Information Assurance--both NSF national centers--to offer workshops and funding supporting cybersecurity faculty professional development at numerous conferences and events.
A mentoring program to support strengthening community college cybersecurity programs to achieve the Center of Academic Excellence (CAE) designation was developed under CWW, enhanced under the C5 NSF grant to WCC, and NCyTE now runs the CAE Candidates program funded by the National Security Agency (NSA). The number of community colleges earning the CAE designation has grown to 118, including seven in California where none existed in 2015. NCyTE was instrumental in facilitating revisions to the CAE designation process and development of the new CAE application tool.
A 20-page internship guide for use by students, employers and faculty members was created and posted to the NCyTE website and has been downloaded over 240 times.


GOAL 2: Expand and improve pathway development opportunities for cybersecurity students throughout the Western region.

 
In additional to sponsoring annual student competitions that promote skills development in a real-world setting, NCyTE hosted annual National Cybersecurity Career Fairs. The fairs brought together 2,700 CAE students and 82 employers under one umbrella in 2020-2021. The fairs are co-sponsored with the CAE Community.


GOAL 3: Serve as a resource for faculty mentoring and lifelong professional development for educators both new to cybersecurity as well as experienced faculty.

 
NCyTE established relationships with 519 faculty from across the nation through workshops and trainings, has assisted 118 community colleges through program development/CAE mentoring, and will continue with this mission as a national center.
An important recent accomplishment was NCyTE's rapid development and offering of Cybersecurity Maturity Model Certificate (CMMC) workshops that trained 60 faculty in addition to providing critical information to business participants needing to meet new Department of Defense (DoD) requirements. The CMMC is a unified standard for implementing cybersecurity across companies included in the defense industrial base, and over 300,000 DoD contractors must meet the new requirement.

GOAL 4: Improve participation and expand partnerships and connections with industry.

 NCyTE sponsored and facilitated 13 "Industry Nights" providing a replicable model that supports colleges to build relationships with regional employers and introduce them to cyber students. One event resulted in an innovative college/employer partnership between ENMU-Ruidoso and the Mescalero Tribe to develop a cyber-range to help students learn cybersecurity skills applicable to the casino industry.  

 

 


Last Modified: 11/22/2021
Modified by: Corrinne Sande
